COMMAND.name: show dhcp client
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To show information of dhcp client on one or all interfaces, use the show dhcp client command in privileged EXEC mode.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: To see more detail information, add verbose at the last of command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: None
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to display DHCP client information on one interfaces: Switch# show dhcp client eth-0-11 eth-0-11 DHCP client information: Current state: HALT Transaction ID: 0xdb1ab113

COMMAND.name: show dhcp client verbose
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To show information of dhcp client on one or all interfaces, use the show dhcp client command in privileged EXEC mode.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: To see more detail information, add verbose at the last of command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: None
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to display DHCP client information: Switch# show dhcp client verbose DHCP client informations: ============================================================ Management interface DHCP client information: Current state: HALT (timeout 14 seconds) Transaction ID: 0x5a21c405

COMMAND.name: show dhcp client statistics
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To show statistics of DHCP client, use the show dhcp client statistics command in privileged EXEC mode.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to show the status of DHCP client, like DHCP packets counter.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: None
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to display DHCP packets statistics: Switch# show dhcp client statistics DHCP client packet statistics: ============================================================ DHCP OFFERS received: 0 DHCP ACKs received: 0 DHCP NAKs received: 0 DHCP Others received: 0 DHCP DISCOVER sent: 0 DHCP DECLINE sent: 0 DHCP RELEASE sent: 0 DHCP REQUEST sent: 0 DHCP packet send failed: 0

COMMAND.name: clear dhcp client statistics
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To clear statistics of dhcp client, use the clear dhcp client statistics command in privileged EXEC mode.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command will clear DHCP packet counter.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: None
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to clear statistics: Switch# clear dhcp client statistics

COMMAND.name: dhcp client broadcast-flag
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify the broadcast-flag in the DHCP message, use the dhcp client broadcast-flag command in global configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This flag tell DHCP server that client can receive unicast IP datagrams until been configured with an IP address. Thus server or relay agent will broadcast any messages to the client on the client’s subnet.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: Broadcast-flag will be set in DHCP message sent by client for request IP address.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to set broadcast-flag: Switch(config)# dhcp client broadcast-flag

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client broadcast-flag
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify the broadcast-flag in the DHCP message, use the dhcp client broadcast-flag command in global configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This flag tell DHCP server that client can receive unicast IP datagrams until been configured with an IP address. Thus server or relay agent will broadcast any messages to the client on the client’s subnet.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: Broadcast-flag will be set in DHCP message sent by client for request IP address.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to delete broadcast-flag: Switch(config)# no dhcp client broadcast-flag

COMMAND.name: dhcp client default-router
COMMAND.help: Set DHCP default router related information

COMMAND.name: dhcp client default-router distance
COMMAND.help: Set the DHCP derived default route metric
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify the default router distance for the routes leased from DHCP server, use the dhcp client default-router distance command in global configuration mode. To remove the configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: None
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default value for the default metric is 254.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify the default router distance: Switch(config)# dhcp client default-router distance 233

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client default-router
COMMAND.help: Set DHCP default router related information

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client default-router distance
COMMAND.help: Set the DHCP derived default route metric
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify the default router distance for the routes leased from DHCP server, use the dhcp client default-router distance command in global configuration mode. To remove the configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: None
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default value for the default metric is 254.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to use the default value of default route metric: Switch(config)# no dhcp client default-router distance

COMMAND.name: management ip address dhcp
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To acquire an IP address for management interface by DHCP, use the management IP address dhcp command in global configuration mode. To disable the function, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command like IP address dhcp.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: DHCP Client is not enabled on management interface.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to enable dhcp client function on management interface: Switch(config-if)# management ip address dhcp

COMMAND.name: no management ip address dhcp
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To acquire an IP address for management interface from by DHCP, use the management IP address dhcp command in global configuration mode. To disable the function, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command like IP address dhcp.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: DHCP Client is not enabled on management interface.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to disable dhcp client function on management interface: Switch(config-if)# no management ip address dhcp

COMMAND.name: dhcp client hostname
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify or modify the hostname sent in the DHCP message; use the dhcp client hostname command in interface configuration mode.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The host name in system will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify name of the host: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client hostname switch

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client hostname
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To remove the hostname sent in the DHCP message, use the no dhcp client hostname.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The host name in system will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to remove the last set: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client hostname

COMMAND.name: dhcp client lease
COMMAND.ACTION:
let lease=0 let lease=${days}*86400 if [ "${hours}" != "" ]; then let lease+=${hours}*3600 fi
if [ "${minutes}" != "" ]; then let lease+=${minutes}*60 fi
cdbctl update/cdb/interface/${iface}/dhclient_if/lease/$lease
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To configure the duration of the lease for an IP address request by DHCP client, use the dhcp client lease command in interface configuration mode. To remove the configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to specify the lease wanted by client, DHCP server may accept this request or ignore it. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: 20 minutes
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify lease 20 minutes for dhcp client: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client lease 0 0 20 The following example shows how to specify lease to infinite for dhcp client: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client lease 0 0 0

COMMAND.name: dhcp client lease infinite
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To configure the infinite lease duration of the lease for an IP address request by DHCP client, use the dhcp client lease infinite command in interface configuration mode. To remove the configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to specify the lease wanted by client, DHCP server may accept this request or ignore it. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: 20 minutes
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how specify infinite lease: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client lease infinite

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client lease
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To configure the duration of the lease for an IP address request by DHCP client, use the dhcp client lease command in interface configuration mode. To remove the configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to specify the lease wanted by client, DHCP server may accept this request or ignore it. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: 20 minutes
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to remove the lease set before: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client lease

COMMAND.name: dhcp client request
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To request configuration parameters by DHCP, use the dhcp client request command in interface configuration mode. To cancel the request, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to request configuration form DHCP server. It can be typed many times with each option or one time with all options wanted. Note that when Option 249 coexist with option 121 then the option 121 should have high priority and option 249 should be ignored. when option 121 or option 249 coexist with option 33 then the option 33 should be ignored. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: static-route, classless-static-route, classless-static-route-ms, tftp-server-address and router is requested as default.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to request dhcp option static-route and tftp-server-address: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client request static-route tftp-server-address The following example shows how to request dhcp option router: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client request router

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client request
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To request configuration parameters by DHCP, use the dhcp client request command in interface configuration mode. To cancel the request, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Use this command to request configuration form DHCP server. It can be typed many times with each option or one time with all options wanted. Note that when Option 249 coexist with option 121 then the option 121 should have high priority and option 249 should be ignored. when option 121 or option 249 coexist with option 33 then the option 33 should be ignored. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: static-route, classless-static-route, classless-static-route-ms, tftp-server-address and router is requested as default.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to cancel request of dhcp option router: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client request router

COMMAND.name: dhcp client class-id
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a class-id for DHCP server and client, use the dhcp client class-id command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Class-id used by DHCP clients to optionally identify the type and configuration of a DHCP client. Vendors and sites may choose to define specific class identifiers to convey particular configuration or other identification information about a client. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: No class-id is set.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify class-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client class-id switch

COMMAND.name: dhcp client class-id hex
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a class-id for DHCP server and client in hex string, use the dhcp client class-id hex command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Class-id used by DHCP clients to optionally identify the type and configuration of a DHCP client. Vendors and sites may choose to define specific class identifiers to convey particular configuration or other identification information about a client. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: No class-id is set.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify class-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client class-id hex abcd

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client class-id
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a class-id for DHCP server and client, use the dhcp client class-id command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Class-id used by DHCP clients to optionally identify the type and configuration of a DHCP client. Vendors and sites may choose to define specific class identifiers to convey particular configuration or other identification information about a client. This command should be issued before ip address dhcp command. If you issued ip address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next ip address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: No class-id is set.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify class-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client class-id switch The following example shows how to delete class-id set before: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client class-id

COMMAND.name: dhcp client client-id
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a client-id used by DHCP server and client for identifying a client, use the dhcp client client-id command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before IP address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default client-id, format of which is like "switch-HWADDR-IFNAME", will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify a client-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client client-id ascii switch-client The following example shows how to delete client-id set before: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client client-id

COMMAND.name: dhcp client client-id ascii
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a client-id used by DHCP server and client for identifying a client in ascii type,use the dhcp client client-id ascii command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before IP address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default client-id, format of which is like "switch-HWADDR-IFNAME", will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify a client-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client client-id ascii switch-client

COMMAND.name: dhcp client client-id hex
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a client-id used by DHCP server and client for identifying a client in ascii type,use the dhcp client client-id hex command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before IP address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default client-id, format of which is like "switch-HWADDR-IFNAME", will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify a client-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client client-id hex abcd

COMMAND.name: no dhcp client client-id
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To specify a client-id used by DHCP server and client for identifying a client, use the dhcp client client-id command in interface configuration mode. To remove this configuration, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: This command should be issued before IP address dhcp command. If you issued IP address dhcp before, this command will take effect after next IP address dhcp command.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: The default client-id, format of which is like "switch-HWADDR-IFNAME", will be used.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to specify a client-id for a interface: Switch(config-if)# dhcp client client-id ascii switch-client The following example shows how to delete client-id set before: Switch(config-if)# no dhcp client client-id

COMMAND.name: ip address dhcp
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To acquire an IP address from Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol(DHCP), use the ip address dhcp command in interface configuration mode. To disable the function, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Once this command was enable on an UP interface, it will acquire IP address immediately, otherwise the DHCP function of the interface will be in SUSPEND status. The no ip address dhcp command will send a DHCPRELEASE message to server and remove any IP address.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: DHCP Client is not enabled on interface.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to enable dhcp client function: Switch(config-if)# ip address dhcp

COMMAND.name: no ip address dhcp
COMMAND.CTCDESCRIPTION: To acquire an IP address from Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol(DHCP), use the ip address dhcp command in interface configuration mode. To disable the function, use the no form of this command.
COMMAND.CTCUSAGE: Once this command was enable on an UP interface, it will acquire IP address immediately, otherwise the DHCP function of the interface will be in SUSPEND status. The no ip address dhcp command will send a DHCPRELEASE message to server and remove any IP address.
COMMAND.CTCDEFAULT: DHCP Client is not enabled on interface.
COMMAND.CTCEXAMPLE: The following example shows how to enable dhcp client function: Switch(config-if)# ip address dhcp The following example shows how to disable dhcp client function: Switch(config-if)# no ip address dhcp
